channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tapes Said to Reveal Polish Minister Disparaging U.S. Ties
item.description: In a new excerpt from secretly recorded conversations, Foreign Minister Radoslaw Sikorski is quoted as describing his country’s security relationship with the United States as “worth nothing.”
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Sunni Militants Capture Major Iraqi Border Post With Syria
item.description: Fighters and weapons are now able to move across the Iraq-Syria border with ease after a three-day fight for Al Qaim, a development Iraq and Western officials called worrisome.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: As Kurdish troops, above, secured an area in the town of Sulaiman Pek in Salahuddin Province in Iraq on Saturday, ISIS militants seized a border post on the Iraq-Syria frontier.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turkey's Best Ally: The Kurds
item.description: After decades of strife, Ankara is cooperating with former enemies.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Debt Vultures' Fell Swoop
item.description: A small group of “holdout” bondholders has used U.S. courts to hold Argentines ransom over their country’s 2001 default.
item.dc:creator: By MARK WEISBROT

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Fooling Mexican Fans
item.description: Mexico’s politicians are pushing through unpopular legislation, while its people are glued to the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCISCO GOLDMAN
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrated this spring in Mexico City against energy reform that would open up the nationalized oil company to foreign investment. Recently, debates on the reform were scheduled at the same time as the World Cup tournament.

item.title: Kerry Hints That U.S. Would Support New Leader for Iraq
item.description: In Cairo on the first leg of a Middle East trip, Secretary of State John Kerry suggested that the United States would be open to a new Iraqi leader, while trying not to appear to intervene.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry met with Sameh Shoukry, the Egyptian foreign minister, after his arrival in Cairo.

item.title: Open Source: Activists Arrested in Cairo at March Against Protest Ban
item.description: Police arrested Egyptians protesting a new law banning unsanctioned street protests on Saturday in Cairo, activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A group of unidentified men attacked a protest in Cairo on Saturday, throwing rocks and bottles, before the police moved in and arrested demonstrators.

item.title: Israeli Youth Dies in Attack Near Syrian Border
item.description: An attack on a defense contractor’s vehicle led to the first fatality on the Israeli side of the border since Syria’s civil war started; two men were also wounded.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Big Voter Turnout in Unofficial Hong Kong Poll
item.description: Three days into a 10-day voting period, more than 600,000 ballots have been cast in a nonbinding poll on the selection of a leader for the city of seven million.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Fugitive Trades Fire With Troops in South Korea
item.description: An army sergeant who killed five fellow soldiers engaged in a shootout with troops chasing him on Sunday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Hong Jin-Hwan-Donga Daily, via Getty Images
item.media:description: South Korean soldiers searched on Sunday for a South Korean Army sergeant who fled his unit on the border with North Korea after killing five fellow soldiers.

item.title: Political Upstarts Work to Propel Change in an Indonesia Tired of Corruption
item.description: A small but growing group of political upstarts is emerging and its members seem united in a belief that the Indonesian public is fed up with the level of corruption in the nation.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, known as the leader of a new wave of politicians, at a mosque in Central Java, Indonesia, this month.

item.title: Ukrainian Church Faces Obscure Pro-Russia Revolt in Its Own Ranks
item.description: Many in western Ukraine suspect that the breakaway church represents a Russian-backed maneuver to destroy a vital wellspring of Ukrainian nationalism.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A priest pouring water on a baby during a blessing ceremony for newborns held at St. George’s Cathedral in Lviv, Ukraine.

item.title: Egyptian Court Confirms Death Penalty for Muslim Brotherhood Defendants
item.description: The action continued a crackdown on Islamists, despite widespread foreign criticism.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Political Upstarts Work to Propel Change in an Indonesia Tired of Corruption
item.description: A small but growing group of political upstarts is emerging and its members seem united in a belief that the Indonesian public is fed up with the level of corruption in the nation.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Joko Widodo, known as the leader of a new wave of politicians, at a mosque in Central Java, Indonesia, this month.

item.title: A Christian Convert, on the Run in Afghanistan
item.description: After an unsuccessful cross-continental journey seeking religious freedom, an apostate Muslim hides near Kabul while family members seek to kill him.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former Muslim prayed somewhere near Kabul, Afghanistan, in hiding from relatives who want to kill him for forsaking Islam and converting to Christianity.

item.title: Iraqi-Americans Watch Chaos in Alarm
item.description: About a fifth of the Iraqis in the United States have come since 2000, meaning many are watching the news with an eye out for at least one family member who might be in harm’s way.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THEODORE SCHLEIFER
item.media:credit: Matthew Ryan Williams for The New York Times
item.media:description: Majid al-Bahadli, an Iraqi native, at home in Seattle. Many relatives are in Baghdad.

item.title: A Largely Indian Victory in World War II, Mostly Forgotten in India
item.description: The memory of the bloodiest battle of the war there, a 1944 encounter that cost the Japanese much of their best army in Burma, is complicated by India’s colonial past.
item.category: Battle of Kohima and Imphal (World War II)
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Ningthoukhangjam Moirangningthou, still living in a house at the foot of a hill that was the site of some of the fiercest fighting, recalled the battle.

item.title: Conflicting Gestures From Putin to Ukraine Leaders
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin accepted the premise of a peace plan proposed by Ukraine’s president, but put Russian troops on combat alert.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A pro-Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine after taking an oath of allegiance to the self-proclaimed Donetsk People’s Republic.

item.title: Sunnis in Iraq Make Some Gains in Fighting in the North and West
item.description: In a split in the coalition supporting the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, the militants clashed with a Baathist faction allied with them, Iraqi security officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: A Kurdish member during a lull in fighting against Sunni militants led by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.

item.title: Opinion: Exiled Mexican Journalists Face Red Tape and Doubt in U.S.
item.description: Journalists from Mexico seeking asylum in the United States enter a bureaucratic nightmare.
item.dc:creator: By MARCELA TURATI
item.media:description: Cameras left by journalists during a 2012 protest against violence in Veracruz.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: For These 2 Women, the Lottery of Birth Decides Opportunity
item.description: Two women, both 20 and talented, have lives that are miles apart. Literally and otherwise, thanks to the lottery of birth.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KRISTOF
item.media:description: Sajan, left, and Nicole Sganga of Notre Dame University bonded easily in northwestern Myanmar. Sajan marveled at the opportunities Nicole has as an American.

item.title: In Shiite Heartland of Iraq, Volunteers Get Set for a ‘Defensive Jihad’
item.description: In Iraq’s Shiite heartland, volunteers have revived battalions of the Mahdi Army, one of the dominant groups preparing for battle after a call for a “defensive jihad” by a high-ranking ayatollah.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Muqtada Munzer, 12, at a rally of Shiites in Najaf on Saturday.

item.title: Answering a Cleric’s Call, Iraqi Shiites Take Up Arms
item.description: Large sections of Baghdad and southern Iraq’s Shiite heartland have been swept up in a mass mobilization, energized by a fatwa urging able-bodied Iraqis to take up arms against Sunni extremists.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: A Mahdi Army rally in the Sadr City neighborhood of Baghdad on Saturday.

item.title: Ballot Counting Continues as Some Afghans Protest
item.description: Supporters of Abdullah Abdullah protested across Kabul demanding that the government address accusations that ballot counting in the runoff election was fraudulent.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A family watched from home as supporters of Abdullah Abdullah shouted slogans in Kabul.

item.title: South Korea Hunts for Army Shooter
item.description: A South Korean Army sergeant killed five of his fellow soldiers and wounded five others on Saturday when he opened fire along the border with North Korea, military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
